title.narrative: Nourrir la population africaine grâce à la recherche : Dialogue de haut niveau sur les politiques (FCRSAI)
Research to Feed Africa: High-Level Policy Dialogue (CIFSRF)

description.narrative:
This project will provide funds for a high-level policy dialogue on applied agriculture and nutrition research at the African Green Revolution Forum. The September 2014 forum is being organized by the Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA) and hosted by the African Union.
The conference is an important opportunity for IDRC to engage in the new vision for agriculture and food security set by African heads of states to mark the Year of Agriculture and Food Security in Africa. Participants will help develop a new agenda for the Comprehensive Africa Agriculture Development Programme, a continental framework for agricultural transformation in Africa.
In 2009, IDRC and the former Canadian International Development Agency (now Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development Canada) launched the five-year CA$62 million Canadian International Food Security Research Fund (CIFSRF). The fund was designed to contribute to solving global problems of food and nutritional insecurity through applied, collaborative research.
The program has supported 21 large applied agriculture and nutrition research consortia in 20 countries. Each is a mix of Canadian and developing-country researchers. These projects have generated a large volume of high-quality research, many with the potential to be scaled up. They include a range of agriculture and nutrition research initiatives, such as: -underutilized and under-researched food crops and aquaculture -enhancing processing technologies for dryland areas -improving nutrition and diets with better food -livestock vaccines and nanotechnology storage.
Participation in the African Green Revolution Forum will support the Fund's objective of using research results to inform food security policies and programs. More than 1,000 policymakers and leaders, including ministers and senior government officials, senior managers of research and development organizations, business leaders, and heads of farming organizations, will participate.
Delegates will discuss the potential for research to offer solutions to feed Africa's hungry people, in particular: -new trends to make agricultural research work for the poor -new pathways to deliver innovative science for impact -win-win entry points to achieve both research and development impact -practical experiences to take innovations to scale.
This project will include a parallel session on the theme of unleashing women's potential to take research to scale and to ensure impact. The panel will identify best practices, technologies, and innovations to help women boost productivity and incomes, create wealth, and become empowered to transform African agriculture and food systems.
The funds will also be used to invite a senior Canadian policymaker (ministerial level) to participate in a high-level panel dialogue with African ministers of agriculture, the president of the African Development Bank, and other leaders from donor organizations on the theme of Upscaling domestic private sector investment in transforming agricultural value chains.
This project provides a strategic opportunity to position CIFSRF as an effective program promoting agricultural growth and nutrition security in the African context.
CIFSRF is organizing the dialogue in collaboration with the Food, Agriculture and Natural Resources Policy Analysis Network (FANRPAN), an Africa-wide agricultural policy think tank.
